title: Acute severe asthma
description: a life-threatening condition characterized by a sudden worsening of asthma symptoms, including severe shortness of breath, wheezing, and difficulty breathing, often requiring emergency treatment.

title: Acute exacerbations of COPD
description: A common medical emergency especially in winter. May be triggered by viral or bacterial infections.

title: Pneumonia
description: An acute lower respiratory tract infection associated with fever, symptoms and signs in the chest, and abnormalities on the chest x-ray

title: Bronchiectasis
description: Chronic inﬂammation of the bronchi and bronchioles leading to permanent dilatation and thinning of these airways.

title: Pulmonary embolism (PE)
description: Venous thrombi, usually from DVT, pass into the pulmonary circulation and block blood fl ow to lungs. The source is often occult.

title: Anaphylactic shock (Anaphylaxis)
description: Type I IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction. Release of histamine and other agents causes: capillary leak; wheeze; cyanosis; oedema (larynx, lids, tongue, lips); urticaria. More common in atopic individuals.

title: Sepsis (Septic shock)
description: Sepsis Life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection

title: Cardiogenic shock
description: Cardiogenic shock is a state of inadequate tissue perfusion primarily due to cardiac dysfunction. It may occur suddenly, or after progressively worsening heart failure.

title: Cardiac tamponade
description: Pericardial fluid accumulates, causing an increase in intrapericardial pressure, which prevents the heart from filling properly and ultimately stops its pumping function.

title: Heat exposure (heat exhaustion)
description: Mentions key items in Heat exposure management.

title: Hemorrhagic shock
description: Mentions key items in Hemorrhagic shock management.

title: Hypovolemic shock
description: Mentions key items in Hypovolemic shock management.

title: Acute coronary syndrome—with ST-elevation (STEMI)
description: Mentions key items in Acute STEMI management.

title: Acute coronary syndrome—without ST-elevation (non STEMI)
description: Mentions key items in Acute Non STEMI management.

title: Severe pulmonary oedema
description: Mentions key items in Acute Non STEMI management.

title: Broad complex tachycardia
description: Ventricular tachycardia (VT) including torsade de pointes, SVT with aberrant conduction, e.g. AF or atrial flutter, with bundle branch block. Pre-excited tachycardias, e.g. AF, atrial flutter, or AV re-entry tachycardia, with underlying WPW.

title: Narrow complex tachycardia
description: Sinus tachycardia, Atrial fibrillation (AF), Atrial flutter, Atrial tachycardia, Multifocal atrial tachycardia, AV nodal re-entry tachycardia, AV re-entry tachycardia (e.g. WPW)

title: Bradycardia
description: The immediate management tends to relate more to cause and adverse signs than to the underlying rhythm, which may be Sinus bradycardia, Heart block, AF with a slow ventricular response, Atrial flutter with a high-degree block, Junctional bradycardia

title: Pneumothorax
description: Mentions key items in pneumothorax management.

title: Acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding
description: Mentions key items in Acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding management.

title: Meningitis
description: Mentions key items in suspected bacterial meningitis and meningococcal sepsis.

title: Encephalitis
description: Suspect encephalitis whenever odd behavior, reduced consciousness, focal neurology, or seizures occur after an infectious prodrome (fever, rash, lymphadenopathy, cold sores, conjunctivitis, or meningeal signs).

title: Cerebral abscess
description: Suspect this in any patient with increased ICP, especially if there is fever or increased TLC. It may follow ear, sinus, dental, or periodontal infection; skull fracture; congenital heart disease; endocarditis; bronchiectasis. It may also occur in the absence of systemic signs of inflammation.

title: Status Epilepticus
description: Seizures lasting for more than 30 minutes or repeated seizures without regaining consciousness between them.

title: Head Injury
description: Mentions key items in head injury management.

title: Raised intracranial pressure (ICP)
description: The volume inside the cranium is ﬁxed, so any increase in the contents can lead to raised ICP. This can be mass effect, edema, or obstruction to ﬂuid outﬂow. Normal ICP in adults is <15mmHg.

title: Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)
description: In acute diabetic ketoacidosis, the body cannot use glucose effectively due to a lack of insulin, so pushing the body into a starvation-like state where ketoacidosis is the only mechanism of energy production.

title: Hypoglycemia
description: Mentions key items in hypoglycemia management.

title: Hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS)
description: Mentions key items in Hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS) management.

title: Lactic acidosis
description: A rare but serious complication of DM with metformin use or septicemia.

title: Myxedema coma
description: The ultimate hypothyroid state before death.

title: Hyperthyroid crisis (thyrotoxic storm)
description: Mentions key items in Hyperthyroid crisis (thyrotoxic storm) management.

title: Addisonian crisis
description: Patients may present in shock, often (but not always) in a patient with known Addison’s, or someone on long-term steroids who has forgotten their tablets. Remember bilateral adrenal hemorrhage (e.g. meningococcemia) as a cause. An alternative presentation is with hypoglycemia

title: Hypopituitary coma
description: Think of decompensated chronic hypophyseal failure whenever hypothermia, refractory hypotension ± septic signs without fever occur with short stature or loss of axillary/pubic hair ± gonadal atrophy.

title: Pheochromocytoma emergencies
description: Patients with pheochromocytoma may have had undiagnosed symptoms for some time, but stress, abdominal palpation, parturition, general anaesthetic, or contrast media used in imaging can cause acute hypertensive crises.

title: Acute poisoning
description: Mentions key items in Acute poisoning management and Some specific poisons and their antidotes.

title: Paracetamol poisoning
description: 12g (=24 tablets) or 150mg/kg in adults may be fatal, If the patient is malnourished then 75mg/kg can kill.

title: Salicylate poisoning
description: Uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation leads to anaerobic metabolism and the production of lactate and heat, Effects are dose related and potentially fatal.

title: Burns
description: The rule of nines: (arm: 9%; front of trunk 18%; head and neck 9%; leg 18%; back of trunk 18%; perineum 1%).

title: Hypothermia
description: Most patients are elderly and do not complain of, or feel, cold, so they have not tried to warm up; In the young, hypothermia is usually from cold exposure

title: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
description: A common progressive disorder characterized by airway obstruction (FEV1 <80% predicted; FEV1/FVC <0.7; see p162 and table 4.5) with little or no reversibility. It includes chronic bronchitis and emphysema.
